pages.raw_output:
<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 193, 304, 209]]<|/det|>
# FURTHER MATHEMATICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 216, 156, 231]]<|/det|>
Paper 1  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[784, 193, 907, 250]]<|/det|>
9231/12 May/June 2013 3 hours  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 259, 467, 303]]<|/det|>
Additional Materials: Answer Booklet/Paper Graph Paper List of Formulae (MF10)  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 322, 390, 338]]<|/det|>
## READ THESE INSTRUCTIONS FIRST  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 351, 828, 367]]<|/det|>
If you have been given an Answer Booklet, follow the instructions on the front cover of the Booklet.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 368, 722, 384]]<|/det|>
Write your Centre number, candidate number and name on all the work you hand in.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 384, 327, 400]]<|/det|>
Write in dark blue or black pen.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 400, 497, 416]]<|/det|>
You may use a soft pencil for any diagrams or graphs.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 416, 601, 432]]<|/det|>
Do not use staples, paper clips, highlighters, glue or correction fluid.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 447, 285, 463]]<|/det|>
Answer all the questions.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 463, 907, 494]]<|/det|>
Give non- exact numerical answers correct to 3 significant figures, or 1 decimal place in the case of angles in degrees, unless a different level of accuracy is specified in the question.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 494, 504, 510]]<|/det|>
The use of a calculator is expected, where appropriate.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 510, 907, 540]]<|/det|>
Results obtained solely from a graphic calculator, without supporting working or reasoning, will not receive credit.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 541, 606, 557]]<|/det|>
You are reminded of the need for clear presentation in your answers.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 571, 606, 586]]<|/det|>
At the end of the examination, fasten all your work securely together.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 587, 757, 603]]<|/det|>
The number of marks is given in brackets [ ] at the end of each question or part question.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 96, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 920, 94]]<|/det|>
Find the area of the region enclosed by the curve with polar equation \(r = 2(1 + \cos \theta)\), for \(0 \leqslant \theta < 2\pi\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 89, 920, 108]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 135, 96, 154]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 135, 833, 156]]<|/det|>
Prove by mathematical induction that \(5^{2n} - 1\) is divisible by 8 for every positive integer \(n\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 135, 920, 155]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 183, 96, 203]]<|/det|>
<label>3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 183, 920, 217]]<|/det|>
The cubic equation \(x^{3} - 2x^{2} - 3x + 4 = 0\) has roots \(\alpha , \beta , \gamma\). Given that \(c = \alpha + \beta + \gamma\), state the value of \(c\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 201, 920, 220]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 228, 826, 248]]<|/det|>
Use the substitution \(y = c - x\) to find a cubic equation whose roots are \(\alpha + \beta\), \(\beta + \gamma\), \(\gamma + \alpha\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 229, 920, 248]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 260, 589, 293]]<|/det|>
Find a cubic equation whose roots are \(\frac{1}{\alpha + \beta}, \frac{1}{\beta + \gamma}, \frac{1}{\gamma + \alpha}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 306, 511, 343]]<|/det|>
Hence evaluate \(\frac{1}{(\alpha + \beta)^2} + \frac{1}{(\beta + \gamma)^2} + \frac{1}{(\gamma + \alpha)^2}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 375, 99, 400]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 371, 636, 415]]<|/det|>
Let \(I_{n} = \int_{0}^{1}\frac{1}{(1 + x^{2})^{n}}\mathrm{d}x\). Prove that, for every positive integer \(n\),

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[395, 421, 601, 442]]<|/det|>
\[2nI_{n + 1} = 2^{-n} + (2n - 1)I_{n}.\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 462, 479, 483]]<|/det|>
Given that \(I_{1} = \frac{1}{4}\pi\), find the exact value of \(I_{3}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 463, 920, 482]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 523, 96, 544]]<|/det|>
<label>5</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 515, 774, 560]]<|/det|>
Use the method of differences to show that \(\sum_{r = 1}^{N} \frac{1}{(2r + 1)(2r + 3)} = \frac{1}{6} - \frac{1}{2(2N + 3)}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 570, 311, 616]]<|/det|>
Deduce that \(\sum_{r = N + 1}^{2N} \frac{1}{(2r + 1)(2r + 3)} < \frac{1}{8N}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 584, 920, 603]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 644, 96, 663]]<|/det|>
<label>6</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 643, 322, 663]]<|/det|>
The matrix \(\mathbf{A}\) is given by

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[420, 664, 579, 714]]<|/det|>
\[\mathbf{A} = \begin{pmatrix} 4 & -5 & 3 \\ 3 & -4 & 3 \\ 1 & -1 & 2 \end{pmatrix}.\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 720, 771, 771]]<|/det|>
Show that \(\mathbf{e} = \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 1 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix}\) is an eigenvector of \(\mathbf{A}\) and state the corresponding eigenvalue.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 732, 920, 752]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 780, 411, 797]]<|/det|>
Find the other two eigenvalues of \(\mathbf{A}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 781, 920, 798]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 810, 320, 828]]<|/det|>
The matrix \(\mathbf{B}\) is given by

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[415, 828, 586, 880]]<|/det|>
\[\mathbf{B} = \begin{pmatrix} -1 & 4 & 0 \\ -1 & 3 & 1 \\ 1 & -1 & 3 \end{pmatrix}.\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 885, 920, 920]]<|/det|>
Show that \(\mathbf{e}\) is an eigenvector of \(\mathbf{B}\) and deduce an eigenvector of the matrix \(\mathbf{AB}\), stating the corresponding eigenvalue.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 902, 920, 920]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 79, 97, 100]]<|/det|>
<label>7</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 920, 121]]<|/det|>
By considering the binomial expansion of \(\left(z - \frac{1}{2}\right)^{6}\), where \(z = \cos \theta + \mathrm{i} \sin \theta\), express \(\sin^{6}\theta\) in the form

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[351, 120, 648, 144]]<|/det|>
\[\frac{1}{32} (p + q \cos 2\theta + r \cos 4\theta + s \cos 6\theta),\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 145, 512, 166]]<|/det|>
where \(p, q, r\) and \(s\) are integers to be determined.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 146, 920, 165]]<|/det|>
<mark>[6]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 180, 920, 217]]<|/det|>
Hence find the exact value of \(\int_{0}^{\frac{1}{4}\pi} \sin^{6} \theta \mathrm{d}\theta .\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 190, 920, 208]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 243, 97, 262]]<|/det|>
<label>8</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 242, 920, 280]]<|/det|>
The linear transformations \(\mathrm{T}_{1}:\mathbb{R}^{4}\to \mathbb{R}^{4}\) and \(\mathrm{T}_{2}:\mathbb{R}^{4}\to \mathbb{R}^{4}\) are represented by the matrices \(\mathbf{M}_{1}\) and \(\mathbf{M}_{2}\) respectively, where

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[240, 280, 761, 356]]<|/det|>
\[\mathbf{M}_{1} = \left( \begin{array}{cccc}1 & -2 & 3 & 5\\ 3 & -4 & 17 & 33\\ 5 & -9 & 20 & 36\\ 4 & -7 & 16 & 29 \end{array} \right)\quad \mathrm{and}\quad \mathbf{M}_{2} = \left( \begin{array}{cccc}1 & -2 & 0 & -3\\ 2 & -1 & 0 & 0\\ 4 & -7 & 1 & -9\\ 6 & -10 & 0 & -14 \end{array} \right).\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 358, 920, 397]]<|/det|>
The null spaces of \(\mathrm{T}_{1}\) and \(\mathrm{T}_{2}\) are denoted by \(K_{1}\) and \(K_{2}\) respectively. Find a basis for \(K_{1}\) and a basis for \(K_{2}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 380, 920, 397]]<|/det|>
<mark>[6]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 406, 920, 477]]<|/det|>
It is given that \(\mathbf{a} = \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 2 \\ 3 \end{pmatrix}\). The vectors \(\mathbf{x}_{1}\) and \(\mathbf{x}_{2}\) are such that \(\mathbf{M}_{1}\mathbf{x}_{1} = \mathbf{M}_{1}\mathbf{a}\) and \(\mathbf{M}_{2}\mathbf{x}_{2} = \mathbf{M}_{2}\mathbf{a}\). Given that \(\mathbf{x}_{1} - \mathbf{x}_{2} = \begin{pmatrix} p \\ 5 \\ 7 \end{pmatrix}\), find \(p\) and \(q\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 496, 920, 515]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 570, 96, 588]]<|/det|>
<label>9</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 568, 358, 588]]<|/det|>
Find \(x\) in terms of \(t\) given that

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[400, 588, 598, 623]]<|/det|>
\[4\frac{\mathrm{d}^{2}x}{\mathrm{d}t^{2}} +4\frac{\mathrm{d}x}{\mathrm{d}t} +x = 6\mathrm{e}^{-2t},\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 630, 437, 660]]<|/det|>
and that, when \(t = 0, x = \frac{5}{3}\) and \(\frac{\mathrm{d}x}{\mathrm{d}t} = \frac{7}{6}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 632, 920, 651]]<|/det|>
<mark>[9]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 673, 212, 692]]<|/det|>
State \(\lim_{t \to \infty} x\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 673, 920, 692]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[280, 800, 717, 821]]<|/det|>
[Questions 10 and 11 are printed on the next page.]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 79, 104, 98]]<|/det|>
<label>10</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 816, 108]]<|/det|>
The curve \(C\) has equation \(y = \frac{2x^{2} - 3x - 2}{x^{2} - 2x + 1}\) . State the equations of the asymptotes of \(C\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 79, 918, 98]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 118, 398, 139]]<|/det|>
Show that \(y \leqslant \frac{25}{12}\) at all points of \(C\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 119, 920, 138]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 149, 524, 170]]<|/det|>
Find the coordinates of any stationary points of \(C\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 151, 920, 170]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 180, 920, 203]]<|/det|>
Sketch \(C\), stating the coordinates of any intersections of \(C\) with the coordinate axes and the asymptotes.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 198, 920, 217]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 228, 102, 247]]<|/det|>
<label>11</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 228, 526, 247]]<|/det|>
Answer only **one** of the following two alternatives.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 267, 201, 286]]<|/det|>
<label>EITHER</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 298, 885, 320]]<|/det|>
The curve \(C\) has equation \(y = 2\sec x\), for \(0\leqslant x\leqslant \frac{1}{4}\pi\). Show that the arc length \(s\) of \(C\) is given by

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[401, 327, 598, 364]]<|/det|>
\[s = \int_{0}^{\frac{1}{4}\pi}(2\sec^{2}x - 1)\mathrm{d}x.\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 336, 920, 355]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 386, 322, 405]]<|/det|>
Find the exact value of \(s\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 386, 920, 405]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 416, 920, 453]]<|/det|>
The surface area generated when \(C\) is rotated through \(2\pi\) radians about the \(x\)-axis is denoted by \(S\). Show that

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[124, 457, 153, 480]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 456, 401, 490]]<|/det|>
\(S = 4\pi \int_{0}^{\frac{1}{4}\pi} (2 \sec^{3}x - \sec x) \mathrm{d}x\),

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 465, 920, 484]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[123, 503, 153, 522]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 501, 420, 528]]<|/det|>
\(\frac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{d}x} (\sec x \tan x) = 2 \sec^3 x - \sec x\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 504, 920, 522]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 540, 374, 560]]<|/det|>
Hence find the exact value of \(S\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 541, 920, 560]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 588, 153, 606]]<|/det|>
<label>OR</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 619, 554, 638]]<|/det|>
The points \(A\), \(B\), \(C\) and \(D\) have coordinates as follows:

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[240, 644, 756, 666]]<|/det|>
\[A\left(2, 1, -2\right),\quad B\left(4, 1, -1\right),\quad C\left(3, -2, -1\right)\quad \mathrm{and}\quad D\left(3, 6, 2\right).\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 672, 792, 693]]<|/det|>
The plane \(\varPi_{1}\) passes through the points \(A\), \(B\) and \(C\). Find a cartesian equation of \(\varPi_{1}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 673, 920, 692]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 702, 897, 722]]<|/det|>
Find the area of triangle \(ABC\) and hence, or otherwise, find the volume of the tetrahedron \(ABCD\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 718, 920, 736]]<|/det|>
<mark>[6]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 732, 698, 752]]<|/det|>
[The volume of a tetrahedron is \(\frac{1}{3} \times\) area of base \(\times\) perpendicular height.]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 763, 915, 784]]<|/det|>
The plane \(\varPi_{2}\) passes through the points \(A\), \(B\) and \(D\). Find the acute angle between \(\varPi_{1}\) and \(\varPi_{2}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 764, 920, 782]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]
